title: Yellen says SEC will prepare report on retail trading volatility

title: Wall Street recedes after disappointing joblessness data, down day for tech
text: 4:15pm: Dow improves but can't squeak out a win The blue-chip index ended Thursday down nearly 120 points, 0.4%, at 31,493 after being down almost 300 earlier in the session. The Nasdaq closed 100 points lower, a 0.7% dip, at 13,865, and the S&P 500 dipped 17 points, 0.4%, to 3,932.

title: US stocks dip as surprise jump in jobless claims sparks recovery concerns
text: US equities closed modestly lower on Thursday after an unexpected increase in weekly jobless claims prompted concerns the labor market's recovery hit a new snag. The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits totaled an unadjusted 861,000 last week, the Labor Department said Thursday morning. The reading lands handily above the 773,000 claims expected by economists surveyed by Bloomberg. The sum is also the highest since mid-January.

title: U.S. stocks finish lower after disappointing data on jobless claims
text: U.S. stocks finished lower on Thursday, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average ended a three-session string of record closing highs, as a drop in retailer Walmart Inc. WMT, -6.41% and a decline in Boeing Co. BA, -3.29% dragged blue chips lower.

title: Strategies For a Rising Rate Environment
text: Bond yields are rising, and that is not a welcome sign for stock market investors. Even though the relationship between bond yields and stock prices tends to vary at different stages of the business cycle, these two variables usually exhibit a negative correlation, suggesting higher bond yields will lead to lower stock prices.

title: How Did Europe's Negative Interest Rates Fare Over the Long Term?
text: In 2014, the European Central Bank lowered key interest rates into negative territory, hoping to encourage growth through spending and investment. Years later, the Fed and other central banks around the world are evaluating whether that made sense.

title: Wall Street shares sink at lunch as traders digest economic data

title: GameStop frenzy brought the market 'dangerously close' to collapse, says Interactive Brokers founder Thomas Petterffy
text: Interactive Brokers Group Chairman and founder Thomas Peterffy said the country's financial markets came "dangerously close" to collapsing during the Reddit-fueled GameStop frenzy last month, more than the public realized. "We have come dangerously close to the collapse of the entire system and the public seems to be completely unaware of that, including Congress and the regulators," Peterffy told CNBC in an interview on Wednesday.

title: Oil prices pare losses as EIA reports a more than 7 million-barrel weekly fall in U.S. crude supplies
